Oops, there's something wrong with the CI, it seems it's not what i modified that leads to the error.

I thought I would post the conclusion.  After digging into this a lot more, I found that the PyDrill driver was returning a dictionary of results.  Making that an `OrderedDict` corrected that problem. 
Thank you @mistercrunch for the assistance as that was really helpful in tracking the dataflow through Superset.
@cgivre you say it's a regression, what changed? If you have updated superset you can try to bisect git changes between releases.
thanks !

Apologies, it's 0.15.1.

Ok I've just cloned the latest master and re-installed Superset, by using `pip install -e ~/superset` (I cloned superset into my home dir). So now I do not get permission errors, but somehow the dashboards are not displaying properly. Clicking on them, I get brought to a page that just shows nothing, like what I've attached here:
[[dashboard] Misc Charts.pdf](https://github.com/airbnb/superset/files/708625/dashboard.Misc.Charts.pdf)
At the same time, when this is happening, I get flask errors like 
`/sqlalchemy/sql/compiler.py:575: SAWarning: Can't resolve label reference 'username asc'; converting to text() (this warning may be suppressed after 10 occurrences)
  util.ellipses_string(element.element))` and `/flask_appbuilder/forms.py:245: FlaskWTFDeprecationWarning: "flask_wtf.Form" has been renamed to "FlaskForm" and will be removed in 1.0.   form = self(obj=obj)`. What is happening now?
If you install from source to have to build the assets like documented here http://airbnb.io/superset/installation.html#making-your-own-build

I used docker on vagrant. 

```
vagrant@debian:~$ cat /proc/meminfo
MemTotal:         506284 kB
```

Ah I see. From the instructions on that link, it looks like building from source would mean I would be installing Superset within my machine's global environment. Is there anyway that I can do this in a Conda environment?

I think this would have to be a new kind of datasource type alongside druid
and sqlalchemy and if you wanted slices to auto update off the feed three
interface for slices and dashboards would have to be adjusted to account
for that. I'm not sure if this much of a paradigm shift is going to be a
useful step for the project. I wonder if tools like statsd and graphite
might be more suitable in the mean time?

locally fine. If you're asking about conda, I'm guessing you're on Windows
where I've found it more painless to run in either vagrant or virtual box.

On the python side i really don't like the let's import everything from a file approach. Airflow take on handling this looks quite a bit more sophisticated to me https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/blob/master/airflow/plugins_manager.py
BTW we now have something similar for custom datasources, see 5a0e06e7 and fc921d63

Could be tricky in this iteration, but plugins for time grains would be a
great addition for our use case.

Sounds good to me, we can think of config vars where one defines the list of things to import.
Any comment on the js part? That's the most annoying imo.

@xrmx I think the difference in approaches can be traced to semantics. Airflow has more of a plugin system which offers extension for an installed instance. @0x0ece's feature may more properly be called a "customization" framework, suitable for those maintaining (and developing on) forks. Personally, I appreciate the functionality and simplicity of the approach.

@alanmcruickshank The `import *` antipattern is mostly referring to cases where the code goes on to use imported components by name. Programmatic import/usage like this is far less offensive, though I agree a full plugin system would have a more refined approach.

I agree with @mahmoud, that's a good point - I should rename the directory to `custom` instead of `plugins`. This is not intended, as in Airflow, to install Superset and load arbitrary code, but to recompile Superset with your code inside. The main reason being of course js.

All right, let's recap then:
- I'll rename `plugins` into `custom`, so the meaning is more clear
- I'll avoid `import *` in favor of a config Ã  la data sources for views and viz

I'll wait for a comment on the js from the FE people, e.g. @ascott, and post an update asap.

As for my specific example:
- we can certainly extract some stuff from the maps and improve the world map, but this will be an independent PR (if anyone wants to jump on it, feel free!)
- custom security and templates can be placed wherever one likes, not necessarily inside the custom -- for me it's a simplification so I can manage everything in a single place
- in short, no action wrt to this PR

@alanmcruickshank BTW, we were using something around these lines: https://github.com/airbnb/superset/pull/1188
but don't have the bandwidth now to port look into that and how it evolved.

@xrmx The same problem +1
I'm using superset 0.15.1 from "pip install".
The datasource is druid.
No matter I choose what in the Time Granularity, itâ€˜s always "granularity": "all" in the Query.
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/21305317/22180893/225adf08-e0b9-11e6-94bc-2c7d1de1288e.png)
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/21305317/22180896/31a3a6de-e0b9-11e6-8c70-17d4c85e3474.png)

I've found that,

viz.py: 
```
 is_timeseries=False(class TableViz)
```

models.py:    
in the following function
```
def query(  # druid
            self, groupby, metrics,
            granularity,
            from_dttm, to_dttm,
            filter=None,  # noqa
            is_timeseries=True,
            timeseries_limit=None,
            timeseries_limit_metric=None,
            row_limit=None,
            inner_from_dttm=None, inner_to_dttm=None,
            orderby=None,
            extras=None,  # noqa
            select=None,  # noqa
            columns=None, ):     

if not is_timeseries:
      granularity = 'all'
```

So in the Table View, is_timeseries is alway false, and it change granularity to 'all',
is that a bug?
They are missing because you have to build them as documented http://airbnb.io/superset/installation.html#making-your-own-build
Please use the template for reporting issues, this is missing too many information to be actionable.
What do you have in the "list table columns" tab of your table for your column? What metric do you want to use on your column?
@JessicaDuan please learn some markdown to better format issue :)
Well, the metric was missing. I assumed that the metrics would appear automatically, as in the case of columns of type INTEGER. Now that I created the metric, it works. Should I change the title?

**Versions Affected:** All up to 0.15.1 (unknown for 0.15.2)
**View:** explore
**Viz:** Table View

**Issue:** Time grain setting has no effect.
**Current Behaviour:** The *TableViz* class in viz.py defaults
*is_timeseries* to false which overrides any granularity given. This is
confusing for new users who haven't got used to it, and it's also a
potential area for a nice feature.
**Potential Fixes:** For any viz which sets *is_timeseries* to false we
grey out the time grain selector to avoid confusion. In addition for the
table viz, it would be great to toggle whether the time grain is used or
not. When it is used, it functions as an additional *Group By* fields and
becomes the first column of the table.
